headline: Big Banks’ Bad Day: Bank of America, Wells Fargo, Citi Sink Most in Months
summary: Shares of some of the largest U.S. banks logged their steepest declines in several months after the lenders reported fourth-quarter earnings that fell short of investors’ high expectations.  Investors found things to like about the reports from Citigroup, Bank of America, and Wells Fargo, such as solid measures of credit quality and positive commentary from executives across the three firms about their investment banking pipelines.  Citigroup stock fell 3.3% to $112.41, its largest decline since October 2025, according to Dow Jones Market Data, while shares of Bank of America fell 3.8% to $52.48, their largest drop since April 2025.

headline: Trump’s Proposed Cap on Card Rates Could Crimp Access to Credit, Says Wells Fargo
summary: Wells Fargo Chief Financial Officer Mike Santomassimo said President Donald Trump’s proposed cap on credit card rates could hurt economic growth and hinder Americans’ ability to access credit, warning of “a negative impact on credit availability.”  The president suggested capping credit card rates at 10% for one year, a move to address voter complaints about the cost of living.  The proposal has gotten a cool reception from Wall Street, and analysts have said that if it takes effect it would force banks to drop lower-income credit card customers.

headline: Wells Fargo fourth-quarter earnings rise as net interest income grows

headline: Wells Fargo Expects Higher Net Interest Income in 2026
summary: Wells Fargo said it expects net interest income to rise to about $50 billion in 2026 from approximately $47.5 billion in 2025 thanks to a growing balance sheet, changes in loan and deposit mix, and repricing of fixed assets.  Net interest income, a key metric for banks, is the difference between what a bank earns on interest-bearing assets and pays in interest on customer deposits.  Wells Fargo’s projection assumes that there will only be two to three cuts in the fed funds rate and the 10-year Treasury will remain relatively stable in 2026, according to a company earnings presentation.
